questions.question_text: What is React primarily used for
options: Building user interfaces
Managing databases
Performing server-side logic
Data analysis
questions.correct_answer: Building user interfaces
questions.explanation: React is a JavaScript library for building interactive user interfaces

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a core feature of React that allows you to write HTML-like code in JavaScript
options: JSX
TypeScript
Babel
Webpack
questions.correct_answer: JSX
questions.explanation: JSX JavaScript XML is a syntax extension for JavaScript that lets you describe UI elements

questions.question_text: How do you define a functional component in React
options: function MyComponent() {}
class MyComponent extends Component {}
const MyComponent = new Component()
var MyComponent = {}
questions.correct_answer: function MyComponent() {}
questions.explanation: Functional components are JavaScript functions that return JSX

questions.question_text: What are props in React
options: Arguments passed into components
Internal state of a component
Lifecycle methods
Event handlers
questions.correct_answer: Arguments passed into components
questions.explanation: Props short for properties are a way of passing data from parent to child components

questions.question_text: Which hook is used to add state to functional components in React
options: useState
useEffect
useContext
useRef
questions.correct_answer: useState
questions.explanation: The useState hook allows functional components to manage their own state

questions.question_text: What is the Virtual DOM in React
options: A lightweight copy of the actual DOM
A server-side rendering technique
A way to style components
A database for component data
questions.correct_answer: A lightweight copy of the actual DOM
questions.explanation: The Virtual DOM is an in-memory representation of the real DOM that React uses for efficient updates

questions.question_text: Which method is used to render a React component into the actual DOM
options: ReactDOM.render()
React.mount()
Component.display()
React.attach()
questions.correct_answer: ReactDOM.render()
questions.explanation: ReactDOM.render is used to render a React element into a DOM node

questions.question_text: When does a React component typically mount
options: When it is first rendered to the DOM
When its state changes
When its props change
When it is removed from the DOM
questions.correct_answer: When it is first rendered to the DOM
questions.explanation: Mounting is the process of putting a component into the DOM for the first time

questions.question_text: What is the primary difference between state and props in React
options: State is internal and mutable props are external and immutable
State is external and mutable props are internal and immutable
Both are internal and mutable
Both are external and immutable
questions.correct_answer: State is internal and mutable props are external and immutable
questions.explanation: State is data managed within a component and can change. Props are data passed from parent to child and are read-only for the child

questions.question_text: When should you use the useEffect hook in a functional component
options: For side effects like data fetching or subscriptions
To declare state variables
To define event handlers
To render JSX conditionally
questions.correct_answer: For side effects like data fetching or subscriptions
questions.explanation: useEffect is used for side effects that occur after rendering such as data fetching setting up subscriptions or manually changing the DOM

questions.question_text: How do you conditionally render a component in React
options: Using a ternary operator or logical AND && in JSX
Using an if-else statement outside JSX
Using a switch statement inside JSX
Using a for loop
questions.correct_answer: Using a ternary operator or logical AND && in JSX
questions.explanation: Conditional rendering in React is often achieved using JavaScript operators like the ternary operator or logical AND && directly within JSX

questions.question_text: What is the main reason for providing a key prop when rendering lists of elements in React
options: To help React efficiently update and reorder list items
To apply unique styles to each item
To define the order of items in the list
To make the items clickable
questions.correct_answer: To help React efficiently update and reorder list items
questions.explanation: Keys help React identify which items have changed are added or are removed making list rendering more efficient and predictable

questions.question_text: How do you handle events like a button click in a React functional component
options: By passing a function directly to an event attribute like onClick={handleClick}
By using addEventListener in useEffect
By defining a method in a separate class
By using an inline string like onClick=handleClick()
questions.correct_answer: By passing a function directly to an event attribute like onClick={handleClick}
questions.explanation: In React event handlers are typically passed as functions directly to the event attributes of JSX elements

questions.question_text: What does component composition mean in React
options: Building complex UIs by combining simpler components
Combining multiple CSS files into one
Using a single component for all UI elements
Breaking down a component into smaller functions
questions.correct_answer: Building complex UIs by combining simpler components
questions.explanation: Component composition is the practice of building complex components by combining simpler reusable components

questions.question_text: What is the primary benefit of using useCallback in React
options: To memoize functions preventing unnecessary re-renders of child components
To memoize values preventing expensive recalculations
To manage asynchronous operations
To create custom hooks
questions.correct_answer: To memoize functions preventing unnecessary re-renders of child components
questions.explanation: useCallback memoizes a function instance so that it is not recreated on every render which can prevent unnecessary re-renders of child components that receive the function as a prop

questions.question_text: When would you prefer using the Context API over prop drilling
options: When many components at different nesting levels need access to the same data
When only immediate child components need data
When data needs to be fetched from an API
When component state needs to be updated frequently
questions.correct_answer: When many components at different nesting levels need access to the same data
questions.explanation: The Context API is ideal for passing data through the component tree without having to pass props down manually at every level prop drilling

questions.question_text: What is a custom hook in React
options: A JavaScript function whose name starts with use and calls other hooks
A special type of component that only manages state
A built-in React hook for advanced logic
A utility for styling components
questions.correct_answer: A JavaScript function whose name starts with use and calls other hooks
questions.explanation: Custom hooks are functions that let you reuse stateful logic across different components. They follow the naming convention useSomething

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of an Error Boundary in React
options: To catch JavaScript errors anywhere in their child component tree log those errors and display a fallback UI
To prevent network requests from failing
To handle errors in asynchronous code
To validate user input in forms
questions.correct_answer: To catch JavaScript errors anywhere in their child component tree log those errors and display a fallback UI
questions.explanation: Error Boundaries are React components that catch JavaScript errors in their child component tree log them and display a fallback UI instead of crashing the whole application

questions.question_text: What is Server-Side Rendering SSR in the context of React
options: Rendering React components to HTML on the server before sending to the client
Rendering React components only on the client-side
Using Nodejs to manage database interactions
Storing component state on the server
questions.correct_answer: Rendering React components to HTML on the server before sending to the client
questions.explanation: SSR involves rendering the initial HTML of a React application on the server which can improve performance and SEO

questions.question_text: How does React determine when to re-render components efficiently
options: By comparing the Virtual DOM with the previous Virtual DOM and applying minimal changes to the real DOM
By constantly polling the real DOM for changes
By re-rendering all components on every state change
By using a complex algorithm that checks every prop and state variable
questions.correct_answer: By comparing the Virtual DOM with the previous Virtual DOM and applying minimal changes to the real DOM
questions.explanation: React uses a process called reconciliation where it compares the new Virtual DOM tree with the previous one to identify differences and then updates only the necessary parts of the real DOM
